metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: XSLT - Editing XML
Data stored in XML files can be edited from an Internet browser.
content.html: Data stored in XML files can be edited from an Internet browser.

content.text: Open, Edit and Save XML
Now, we will show how to open, edit, and save an XML file that is stored on the server.
content.html: Now, we will show how to open, edit, and save an XML file that is stored on the server.

content.text: We will use XSL to transform the XML document into an HTML form. The values of the XML elements will be written to HTML input fields in an HTML form. The HTML form is editable. After editing the data, the data is going to be submitted back to the server and the XML file will be updated (we will show code for both PHP and ASP).
content.html: We will use XSL to transform the XML document into an HTML form. The values of the XML elements will be written to HTML input fields in an HTML form. The HTML form is editable. After editing the data, the data is going to be submitted back to the server and the XML file will be updated (we will show code for both PHP and ASP).

content.text: The XML File and the XSL File
First, take a look at the XML document ("tool.xml"):
content.html: First, take a look at the XML document ("tool.xml"):

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<tool>


<field id="prodName">


<value>HAMMER HG2606</value>


</field>


<field id="prodNo">


<value>32456240</value>


</field>


<field id="price">


<value>$30.00</value>


</field>

</tool>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<tool>
  <field id="prodName">
    <value>HAMMER HG2606</value>
  </field>
  <field id="prodNo">
    <value>32456240</value>
  </field>
  <field id="price">
    <value>$30.00</value>
  </field>
</tool>

content.text: View the XML file .
Then, take a look at the following style sheet ("tool.xsl"):
content.html: Then, take a look at the following style sheet ("tool.xsl"):

content.code: Tool Information (edit):
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xsl:stylesheet version="1.0"
xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform">

<xsl:template match="/">
  <html>
  <body>
  <form method="post" action="edittool.asp">
  <h2>Tool Information (edit):</h2>
  <table border="0">
    <xsl:for-each select="tool/field">
    <tr>
      <td><xsl:value-of select="@id"/></td>
      <td>
      <input type="text">
      <xsl:attribute name="id">
        <xsl:value-of select="@id" />
      </xsl:attribute>
      <xsl:attribute name="name">
        <xsl:value-of select="@id" />
      </xsl:attribute>
      <xsl:attribute name="value">
        <xsl:value-of select="value" />
      </xsl:attribute>
      </input>
      </td>
    </tr>
    </xsl:for-each>
  </table>
  <br />
  <input type="submit" id="btn_sub" name="btn_sub" value="Submit" />
  <input type="reset" id="btn_res" name="btn_res" value="Reset" />
  </form>
  </body>
  </html>
</xsl:template>

</xsl:stylesheet>

content.text: View the XSL file .

The XSL file above loops through the elements in the XML file and creates one input field for each XML "field" element. The value of the XML "field" element's "id" attribute is added to both the "id" and "name" attributes of each HTML input field. The value of each XML "value" element is added to the "value" attribute of each HTML input field. The result is an editable HTML form that contains the values from the XML file.
content.html: The XSL file above loops through the elements in the XML file and creates one input field for each XML "field" element. The value of the XML "field" element's "id" attribute is added to both the "id" and "name" attributes of each HTML input field. The value of each XML "value" element is added to the "value" attribute of each HTML input field. The result is an editable HTML form that contains the values from the XML file.

content.text: Then, we have a second style sheet: "tool_updated.xsl". This is the XSL file that will be used to display the updated XML data. This style sheet will not result in an editable HTML form, but a static HTML table:
content.html: Then, we have a second style sheet: "tool_updated.xsl". This is the XSL file that will be used to display the updated XML data. This style sheet will not result in an editable HTML form, but a static HTML table:

content.code: Updated Tool Information:
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xsl:stylesheet version="1.0"
xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform">

<xsl:template match="/">
  <html>
  <body>
  <h2>Updated Tool Information:</h2>
  <table border="1">
    <xsl:for-each select="tool/field">
    <tr>
      <td><xsl:value-of select="@id" /></td>
      <td><xsl:value-of select="value" /></td>
    </tr>
    </xsl:for-each>
  </table>
  </body>
  </html>
</xsl:template>

</xsl:stylesheet>

content.text: View the XSL file .
The PHP File
In the "tool.xsl" file above, change the HTML form's action attribute to "edittool.php".
content.html: In the "tool.xsl" file above, change the HTML form's action attribute to "edittool.php".

content.text: The "edittool.php" page contains two functions: The loadFile() function loads and transforms the XML file for display and the updateFile() function applies the changes to the XML file:
content.html: The "edittool.php" page contains two functions: The loadFile() function loads and transforms the XML file for display and the updateFile() function applies the changes to the XML file:

content.code:
<?php
function loadFile($xml, $xsl)
{
$xmlDoc = new DOMDocument();

$xmlDoc->load($xml);

$xslDoc = new DOMDocument();
$xslDoc->load($xsl);


$proc = new XSLTProcessor();
$proc->importStyleSheet($xslDoc);

echo $proc->transformToXML($xmlDoc);
}

function updateFile($xml)

{
$xmlLoad = simplexml_load_file($xml);
$postKeys = array_keys($_POST);


foreach($xmlLoad->children() as $x)
{ 
  foreach($_POST as 
$key=>$value)
  { 
    if($key == 
$x->attributes())
    { 
      
$x->value = $value;
    }
  }
} 

$xmlLoad->asXML($xml);

loadFile($xml,"tool_updated.xsl");
}

if($_POST["btn_sub"] == "")

{
  loadFile("tool.xml", "tool.xsl");
}
else
{
  
updateFile("tool.xml");
}
?>
content.code_html:
<?php
function loadFile($xml, $xsl)
{
$xmlDoc = new DOMDocument();
$xmlDoc->load($xml);

$xslDoc = new DOMDocument();
$xslDoc->load($xsl);

$proc = new XSLTProcessor();
$proc->importStyleSheet($xslDoc);
echo $proc->transformToXML($xmlDoc);
}

function updateFile($xml)
{
$xmlLoad = simplexml_load_file($xml);
$postKeys = array_keys($_POST);

foreach($xmlLoad->children() as $x)
{
  foreach($_POST as $key=>$value)
  {
    if($key == $x->attributes())
    {
      $x->value = $value;
    }
  }
}

$xmlLoad->asXML($xml);
loadFile($xml,"tool_updated.xsl");
}

if($_POST["btn_sub"] == "")
{
  loadFile("tool.xml", "tool.xsl");
}
else
{
  updateFile("tool.xml");
}
?>

content.text: Tip: If you don't know how to write PHP, please study our PHP tutorial .
content.html: Tip: If you don't know how to write PHP, please study our PHP tutorial.

content.text: Note: We are doing the transformation and applying the changes to the XML file on the server. This is a cross-browser solution. The client will only get HTML back from the server - which will work in any browser.
content.html: Note: We are doing the transformation and applying the changes to the XML file on the server. This is a cross-browser solution. The client will only get HTML back from the server - which will work in any browser.

content.text: The ASP File
The HTML form in the "tool.xsl" file above has an action attribute with a value of "edittool.asp".
content.html: The HTML form in the "tool.xsl" file above has an action attribute with a value of "edittool.asp".

content.text: The "edittool.asp" page contains two functions: The loadFile() function loads and transforms the XML file for display and the updateFile() function applies the changes to the XML file:
content.html: The "edittool.asp" page contains two functions: The loadFile() function loads and transforms the XML file for display and the updateFile() function applies the changes to the XML file:

content.code:
<%

function loadFile(xmlfile,xslfile)

Dim xmlDoc,xslDoc
'Load XML and XSL file

set xmlDoc = Server.CreateObject("Microsoft.XMLDOM")

xmlDoc.async = false

xmlDoc.load(xmlfile)
set xslDoc = Server.CreateObject("Microsoft.XMLDOM")

xslDoc.async = false

xslDoc.load(xslfile)
'Transform file

Response.Write(xmlDoc.transformNode(xslDoc))

end function


function updateFile(xmlfile)

Dim xmlDoc,rootEl,f

Dim i
'Load XML file

set xmlDoc = Server.CreateObject("Microsoft.XMLDOM")

xmlDoc.async = false

xmlDoc.load(xmlfile)


'Set the rootEl variable equal to the root element

Set rootEl = xmlDoc.documentElement


'Loop through the form collection

for i = 1 To Request.Form.Count


'Eliminate button elements in the form


if instr(1,Request.Form.Key(i),"btn_")=0 then


'The selectSingleNode method queries the XML file for a single node


'that matches a query. This query requests the value element that is


'the child of a field element that has an id attribute which matches


'the current key value in the Form Collection. When there is a match -


'set the text property equal to the value of the current field in the


'Form Collection.


set f = rootEl.selectSingleNode("field[@id='" & _


Request.Form.Key(i) & "']/value")


f.Text = Request.Form(i)


end if

next


'Save the modified XML file

xmlDoc.save xmlfile


'Release all object references

set xmlDoc=nothing

set rootEl=nothing

set f=nothing


'Load the modified XML file with a style sheet that

'allows the client to see the edited information

loadFile xmlfile,server.MapPath("tool_updated.xsl")

end function


'If form is submitted, update the XML file and display result

' - if not, transform the XML file for editing

if Request.Form("btn_sub")="" then


loadFile server.MapPath("tool.xml"),server.MapPath("tool.xsl")

else


updateFile server.MapPath("tool.xml")

end if

%>
content.code_html:
<%
function loadFile(xmlfile,xslfile)
Dim xmlDoc,xslDoc
'Load XML and XSL file
set xmlDoc = Server.CreateObject("Microsoft.XMLDOM")
xmlDoc.async = false
xmlDoc.load(xmlfile)
set xslDoc = Server.CreateObject("Microsoft.XMLDOM")
xslDoc.async = false
xslDoc.load(xslfile)
'Transform file
Response.Write(xmlDoc.transformNode(xslDoc))
end function

function updateFile(xmlfile)
Dim xmlDoc,rootEl,f
Dim i
'Load XML file
set xmlDoc = Server.CreateObject("Microsoft.XMLDOM")
xmlDoc.async = false
xmlDoc.load(xmlfile)

'Set the rootEl variable equal to the root element
Set rootEl = xmlDoc.documentElement

'Loop through the form collection
for i = 1 To Request.Form.Count
  'Eliminate button elements in the form
  if instr(1,Request.Form.Key(i),"btn_")=0 then
    'The selectSingleNode method queries the XML file for a single node
    'that matches a query. This query requests the value element that is
    'the child of a field element that has an id attribute which matches
    'the current key value in the Form Collection. When there is a match -
    'set the text property equal to the value of the current field in the
    'Form Collection.
    set f = rootEl.selectSingleNode("field[@id='" & _
    Request.Form.Key(i) & "']/value")
    f.Text = Request.Form(i)
  end if
next

'Save the modified XML file
xmlDoc.save xmlfile

'Release all object references
set xmlDoc=nothing
set rootEl=nothing
set f=nothing

'Load the modified XML file with a style sheet that
'allows the client to see the edited information
loadFile xmlfile,server.MapPath("tool_updated.xsl")
end function

'If form is submitted, update the XML file and display result
' - if not, transform the XML file for editing
if Request.Form("btn_sub")="" then
  loadFile server.MapPath("tool.xml"),server.MapPath("tool.xsl")
else
  updateFile server.MapPath("tool.xml")
end if
%>
